info.name: Before and After: APIs for Split Admins
info.description: This collection provides working examples of the following: - Split API endpoints which will be deprecated after a Split account is migrated to Harness. - Harness API endpoints that will replace the deprecated API endpoints. In each folder, you will see a "Split (BEFORE)" and "Harness (AFTER)" subfolder. These contain working examples of how Split Admin API tasks are performed in Split today, paired with working examples of how those same tasks can be performed in a Split account once it is migrated to Harness. The folder names are based on endpoint names that Split adminstrators will be familiar with: while there is no "Restrictions" endpoint on the Harness side, we document the replacement for Split's Restrictions (project view permissions control) endpoints under Restrictions > Harness (AFTER). **Important: You will need a Harness API Key to operate against the new Harness API endpoints.** Harness API Keys are created in Harness under Acccount Settings > Access Control > Service Accounts. API Keys created there with the proper role and scope will be able to hit both the new endpoints on Harness, and the go-forward endpoints not being deprecated on Split. The diagram below shows what type of API key can be used and when:

item.name: Users
Split (BEFORE)

request.description:
List all active, deactivated, and pending users in the organization.

Also supports getting a list of users in a group with optional query param, group_id.

**Legacy Split API doc link:** [https://docs.split.io/reference/list-users](https://docs.split.io/reference/list-users)

Get a user by their user Id.

**Legacy Split API doc link:** [https://docs.split.io/reference/get-user](https://docs.split.io/reference/get-user)

response.name: Successful removal of user from group

item.description:
The `/users` endpoint becomes unavailable to you once your account has been migrated to Harness.

See the overview in the Users folder above this one for a side-by-side comparison of how users are managed in Split vs Harness.

### Deleting and Disabling Users

- Split supports the deletion of pending users only.
    
- Split supports a disabled user state. Harness does not.
    

### Group Membership: Managed by This Endpoint

In addition to **CRUD operations on users**, this endpoint is where **group membership** **operations** are performed in Split. For that reason, you will find these group-related examples here under Users, instead of in the Groups folder:

- List Users (optionally takes group as filter)
    
- Add User to Group
    
- Remove User from Group

item.name: Harness (AFTER)

response.name: 200 OK - Get List of Users Example
Successful User Update (200 OK)
response.body:
{
  "resource": {
    "uuid": "wtW6nhcYS5KqUqEeekMtuA",
    "name": "Johannes Liegl",
    "email": "johannes.liegl+demo@harness.io",
    "locked": false,
    "disabled": false,
    "external": false,
    "createdAt": 1700000000000,
    "updatedAt": 1700000001000
  },
  "created": false,
  "updated": true,
  "metaData": null,
  "correlationId": "string"
}

response.name: Successful User Invitation (201 Created)
204 No Content - Pending User Deleted
response.body: No content is returned when a pending user is successfully deleted.

request.description:
**Harness API doc link - Get pending users:** [https://apidocs.harness.io/invite/getpendingusersaggregated](https://apidocs.harness.io/invite/getpendingusersaggregated)

See also:

**Harness API doc link - List Invites:** [https://apidocs.harness.io/invite/getinvites](https://apidocs.harness.io/invite/getinvites)

item.description:
The `/user` and `/invites` endpoints here replace the Split `/users` endpoint after migration.

See the overview in the Users folder above this one for a side-by-side comparison of how users are managed in Split vs Harness.

### Deleting and Disabling Users

- Harness supports the deletion of pending and active users.
    
- Harness does not support a disabled user state because of conflicts that can create with different SCIM providers

In Split, adding a user to the system automatically granted them a fixed set of global permissions. In Harness, you have **greater control over user permissions**. Refer to the section below this table to understand how **migrated users receive their permissions automatically**, and why you must **exercise more care when creating new users via the API**.

**How Users Are Managed Differently in Split vs. Harness**

| **Aspect** | **Split** (Before) | **Harness** (After) |
| --- | --- | --- |
| **User Roles** | Users were either **Administrators, Editors, or Viewers**, with hardcoded roles. | Users can be **assigned any role**, scoped to **any resource group**. Roles can be granted directly or through **group membership**. |
| **User Scope** | Users had a **global account-level scope**. | Users exist at **Account, Organization, or Project levels**, allowing for more fine-grained access control. |
| **Role Assignment** | Roles were **fixed per user** and could not be customized. | Roles are **assigned dynamically** based on **role bindings** that link users to **specific permissions and resource groups**. |
| **User Creation** | Users were created via **direct API calls** with limited configuration options. | Users are created with **explicit role assignments** and can be added to groups that define their access. |
| **Access Control** | Permissions were set **individually** per user or through environment-level settings. | Permissions are **inherited from roles and groups**, allowing for **centralized permission management**. |
| **User Group Membership** | Groups were **lists of users** with no assigned permissions, except for Administrators. | Groups can be **granted roles**, and users automatically inherit the permissions assigned to the group. |

---

### **Observing Migrated Users vs. Creating New Users in Harness**

When working with **users in Harness after migrating from Split**, it is essential to distinguish between how **migrated users** got their permissions and the steps you take to grant permissions when adding **new users post-migration**. Please pay particular attention to the way group memberships control most of this process. Let us know if you have questions!

---

### **Migrated Users: Automatically Configured with Correct Roles and Scope**

- **During the migration**, all existing users from Split will be **pre-configured with the appropriate roles and scope** that match their previous access levels.
    
- These users will be assigned the correct **roles, resource groups, and permissions** to ensure they can continue working as they did in Split **without additional manual configuration**.
    
- If acting on a migrated user (e.g., modifying roles, adding them to new groups), ensure that **any changes align with their intended level of access** to avoid accidental over-permissioning or restriction.
    

---

### **Creating New Users Post-Migration: Manual Role and Scope Assignment Required**

- **New users do not inherit automatic permissions**—they must be explicitly assigned the correct **role(s) and scope**.
    
- When adding a new user, consider:
    
    - **Role Selection:** Assign the correct role based on what the user needs to do (e.g., `project_viewer`, `fme_manager`).
        
    - **Scope Definition:** Determine whether the user should have access at the **Account, Organization, or Project level**.
        
    - **Group Membership:** Adding users to **pre-configured groups** (e.g., `_all_account_fme_editors_`) can help apply the correct permissions more efficiently.
        

---

### **Key Considerations for API Users**

✔ **Migrated users already have the correct permissions—modify them only if necessary.**

✔ **New users require manual role and scope assignment—apply permissions carefully.**

✔ **Use role bindings to assign access in a structured, scalable way.**

✔ **Double-check the scope of new users to ensure they have access to the right resources without over-permissioning.**

item.name: Groups
Split (BEFORE)

request.description:
List all active groups in the organization.

**Legacy Split API doc link:** [https://docs.split.io/reference/list-groups](https://docs.split.io/reference/list-groups)

    "user1@example.com",

request.description:
**Update Group**

Updates the name and description of a specific group in Split.

**Endpoint:**  
PUT `/groups/{{Split_Group_Identifier}}`

**Path Parameter:**

- `Split_Group_Identifier`: The unique identifier of the group to update.
    

**Request Body (JSON):**

``` json
{
  "name": "string",         // The new name for the group.
  "description": "string"   // The new description for the group.
}

 ```

**Behavior:**  
This request modifies the specified group's details. Ensure you have the correct group identifier and provide both fields in the request body.

**Legacy Split API doc link:** [https://docs.split.io/reference/update-group](https://docs.split.io/reference/update-group)

variable.description: Unique identifier for the group to delete

item.description:
The `/groups` endpoint becomes unavailable to you once your account has been migrated to Harness.

- This endpoint manages data **about** each group, **not its list of members**.
    
- For **management of members** _**in**_ **each group** see these examples in Users:
    
    - List Users (optionally takes group as filter)
        
    - Add User to Group
        
    - Remove User from Group

Successful Response (200 OK)

response.name: Successful Group Update

item.description:
The `/user-groups` endpoint here replaces the Split `/groups` and `/users` endpoints after migration.

### **How User Groups Are Used in Harness**

In **Harness**, user groups function differently from **Split**, providing greater flexibility in managing permissions and access control.

#### **Key Ways User Groups Are Used in Harness:**

1. **User Groups Can Have Role Bindings**
    
    - In **Split**, groups were just lists of users with no assigned roles (except for Administrators).
        
    - In **Harness**, user groups **can be assigned one or more roles**, which determine what actions members can perform.
        
2. **Groups Can Exist at Different Levels**
    
    - In **Split**, all groups were **global (account-level only)**.
        
    - In **Harness**, groups can be created at the **Account, Organization, or Project level**, allowing for **more granular access control**.
        
3. **User Groups Control Access in RBAC**
    
    - In **Split**, groups granted access only be being included in **environment or object-level permissions** settings.
        
    - In **Harness**, groups are used **directly in Role Assignments (Role Bindings)** to manage access.
        
4. **Default Groups for Migrated Users**
    
    - **Harness automatically creates certain groups during migration** to mimic Split’s open-access behavior outside of restricted projects:
        
        - `_all_account_admins_` → Full access
            
        - `_all_account_fme_editors_` → Editing permissions
            
        - `_all_account_fme_viewers_` → Read-only access.
            

---

### **Key Takeaways**

✔ **Harness user groups manage permissions through role bindings, not just membership.**

✔ **Groups exist at multiple levels (Account, Org, Project), unlike Split’s global groups.**

✔ **User Groups are used in RBAC to assign permissions efficiently.**

### **How Groups Are Administered Differently in Split vs. Harness**

| **Aspect** | **Split (Before)** | **Harness (After)** |
| --- | --- | --- |
| **Group Functionality** | Groups are simple **lists of users**, except for the Administrators group. | Groups can have **role bindings**, meaning they can grant permissions. |
| **Permissions** | Groups themselves **do not have roles**; permissions are granted via environment/object-level settings. | Groups can be assigned **one or more roles**, defining what actions members can perform. |
| **Scope** | Groups are **global (account-level only)**—they cannot be scoped to a project. | Groups can exist at **Account, Organization, or Project level**, providing flexibility. |
| **Creating a Group** | Admins create a group with only a **name and description**. | Admins create a group and can assign **users, roles, and notification settings**. |
| **Managing Membership** | Users are **added or removed manually** through the Users API. | Users can be added or removed, and their **permissions are determined by the group's assigned roles**. |
| **Using Groups for Permissions** | Groups grant permissions **only when used in environment or object-level entries**. | Groups can be assigned **roles directly**, making them the preferred way to manage access. |
| **Default Groups in Migration** | Only the **Administrators group** had special privileges. | Migrated users are assigned to **new default groups**: `_all_account_admins_`, `_all_account_fme_editors_`, `_all_account_fme_viewers_`. |

---

### **Key Takeaways**

✔ **Split groups were just lists of users; Harness groups can have assigned roles.**

✔ **Harness supports hierarchical groups at different scopes (Account, Organization, Project).**

✔ **Within Harness, groups are the preferred way to manage permissions, reducing manual role assignments.**

item.name: Projects
Split (BEFORE)

request.description:
Retrieves the Workspaces for an organization.

The result set of the API may be subject to reduction based on the Workspace View Restrictions.

**Legacy Split API doc link:** [https://docs.split.io/reference/get-workspaces](https://docs.split.io/reference/get-workspaces)

Allows you to create workspaces.

Note: When you create a workspace from this API, this won't create the default environment. You must use the create environment API to create an environment.

**Legacy Split API doc link:** [https://docs.split.io/reference/create-workspace](https://docs.split.io/reference/create-workspace)

This endpoint provides a partial update for a workspace.

**Legacy Split API doc link:** [https://docs.split.io/reference/update-workspace](https://docs.split.io/reference/update-workspace)

Deletes a workspace.

**Legacy Split API doc link:** [https://docs.split.io/reference/delete-workspace](https://docs.split.io/reference/delete-workspace)

variable.description: Unique identifier for the workspace to delete

item.description:
`POST /workspaces`, `PATCH /workspaces`, and `DELETE /workspaces` will become unavailable when your account is migrated to Harness.

`GET /workspaces` will **not** be deprecated, to support lookup of the `wsId` corresponding to a Harness Project `name`. Please see the Harness (AFTER) folder below for details.

item.name: Harness (AFTER)

response.name: Successful Project Deletion (204 No Content)

variable.description: The identifier of the Harness project to delete

response.body: Project deleted successfully. No content returned.

item.description:
The `/projects` endpoint here replaces the `POST`, `PATCH`, and `DELETE` verbs for the Split `/workspaces` endpoint after migration.

The `GET` verb for the Split `/workspaces` endpoint will **not** be deprecated, in order to address the following use case:

#### **Retrieving** **`wsId`** **Using the Harness Project Name**

In many of the remaining Split Admin API endpoints, you will need a workspace ID, often abbreviated as `ws` or `wsId`. Here is how you can obtain the `wsId` that corresponds to a Harness project:

1. **Use the** **`filter`** **Option in GET Workspaces:** Submit GET /workspaces request to the Split Admin API that used the optional query param `name` and the value of the Harness Project `name` (not the Harness Project `identifier`).
    
2. **Extract the** **`wsId`** **from the Response:** Once the API returns the filtered result, the **workspace ID (**`wsId`**)** will be included in the response alongside the project name.
    

Note: The usage pattern here (using the editable `name` rather than the permanent `identifier`) differs from the typical Harness API pattern, but it is the correct pattern to use when calling this Split Admin API endpoint.

### **How Projects Are Managed in Split vs. Harness**

| **Aspect** | **Split** | **Harness** |
| --- | --- | --- |
| **Terminology** | Projects were called **Workspaces** until late 2024, when interfaces and documentation switched to the term **Projects**. The API retained the term **Workspaces.** | Projects are called **Projects** and are integrated into the **RBAC hierarchy** (Account → Organization → Project). |
| **Scope & Structure** | Workspaces are managed independently and have no explicit hierarchy. | Projects exist within **Organizations** and **Accounts**, enabling structured role-based access. |
| **Access Management** | Access is managed via **Project View Restrictions**, which require explicit API calls to set visibility. | Projects are **restricted by default**, and access is controlled using **RBAC role assignments and resource groups**. |
| **Permissions & Roles** | Permissions are assigned per user or group via manual restrictions. | Permissions are assigned through **Roles and Resource Groups**, which can be inherited or explicitly defined. |
| **Creating a Project** | Creating a new project (workspace) requires a **direct API call**, specifying only a name and optional settings. | Creating a project involves defining its **scope within the Account/Organization**, and **RBAC settings determine who can access and modify it**. |
| **Project Restrictions** | Open workspaces are **the default**, but can be explicitly restricted via API. | Projects are **restricted by default**, and broad access must be explicitly granted via role bindings. |

---

### **Key Takeaways**

✔ **Harness projects follow a structured hierarchy (Account → Organization → Project), unlike Split’s flat workspace model.**  
  
✔ **RBAC replaces manual project restrictions, offering more flexible and scalable access management.**  
  
✔ **Projects are restricted by default in Harness, whereas Split workspaces are open by default unless restricted.**

item.name: API Keys
Split (BEFORE)

request.description:
Create and add an API key to your organization.

**Legacy Split API doc link:** [https://docs.split.io/reference/create-an-api-key](https://docs.split.io/reference/create-an-api-key)

item.description:
`POST /apiKeys` (Split Admin API key **creation)** will not available for the `admin` type API keys after your migration date.

`DEL /apiKeys` (Split Admin API key **deletion)** will remain available for the `admin` type API keys after your migration date, but only to delete those keys created _before your migration_.

### **SDK API Key Management Remains at This Endpoint**

Continue to use this endpoint for `client_side` and `server_side` SDK API Key management.

### **How Admin API Keys Are Managed in Split**

In **Split**, API key management operates differently from **Harness**, particularly in how permissions and scopes are assigned.

1. **API Keys Have Direct Permissions:**
    
    - Each API key is **individually assigned roles and scopes**.
        
    - API keys control access to resources **without a service account concept**.
        
    - Permissions are set directly on each key, rather than inheriting permissions from a parent entity.
        
2. **Scopes Are Defined at the Key Level:**
    
    - API keys are tied to **specific resource scopes**, such as workspaces, users, or groups.
        
    - Users must carefully manage the scope to ensure that API keys have appropriate access.
        
3. **Manual Rotation and Expiration Handling:**
    
    - API key rotation is manual.
        
    - There is no built-in expiration mechanism—users must **delete and recreate keys** to manage security.
        

---

### **How It Works Differently in Harness**

- API keys **no longer define permissions** themselves. Instead:
    
    1. **Permissions are managed at the Service Account level**.
        
    2. **API keys inherit permissions from their parent Service Account**.
        
    3. **Tokens provide additional security and expiration settings**.

item.description:
The `/serviceaccount`, `/apikey`, `/token`, and `/roleassignments` endpoints here replace the Split `/apiKeys` endpoint after migration to Harness.

Here are the **Harness API equivalents** for replacing the **Split API key creation process**, which now requires **three components**:

1. **Service Account**
    
2. **API Key**
    
3. **Token**
    

---

## **Step 1: Create a Service Account**

Before creating an API key, you must first create a **Service Account** since API keys are scoped under a **Service Account**.

👉 **Save the** **`identifier`** **from the response to use in the next step as** `SERVICE_ACCOUNT_ID`

---

## **Step 2: Create an API Key**

Now that the Service Account is created, you can generate an **API Key**.

👉 **Save the** **`identifier`** **from the response to use in the next step as** `API_KEY_ID`

---

## **Step 3: Create a Token for the API Key**

Finally, you need to create a **Token** to use with the API Key.

👉 **Save the** **`token`** **value to use in API calls as the bearer token.**

---

# More Details on Harness API Key Structure

## Service Account > API Key > Token

While Split Admin API keys were a single entity, in Harness they consist of three entities at different levels for greater control.

## **1\. Service Account Level**

- **Primary Role:** Defines **who** (a machine identity) is making API requests.
    
- **What Can Be Set Here?**
    
    - **Permissions & Roles**: Permissions are assigned at the **Service Account level**, not at the API Key or Token level.
        
    - **Scope**: A Service Account can be scoped at **Account, Organization, or Project level**.
        
    - **Ownership of API Keys**: Each API Key is linked to a specific **Service Account**.
        
- **Key Takeaway:** **Permissions are set at the Service Account level, and all API Keys created under it inherit these permissions.**
    

## **2\. API Key Level**

- **Primary Role:** Acts as an **access credential** tied to a Service Account.
    
- **What Can Be Set Here?**
    
    - **Scope**: An API Key belongs to a specific **Service Account**, meaning it has the same permissions.
        
    - **Token Generation**: Each API Key can have multiple **Tokens** for authentication.
        
    - **Expiry Control**: API Keys **do not expire** unless explicitly deleted.
        
- **Key Takeaway:** **API Keys provide authentication, but they do not define permissions themselves.**
    

## **3\. Token Level**

- **Primary Role:** A short-lived, displayed-once **credential** used to authenticate requests.
    
- **What Can Be Set Here?**
    
    - **Expiration Date**: Tokens can have an **expiration time** (or be permanent).
        
    - **One-Time Visibility**: A token is **only shown once** when created.
        
    - **Rotatable**: Tokens can be **revoked and rotated** without affecting the API Key.
        
- **Key Takeaway:** **Tokens are temporary authentication mechanisms derived from API Keys. They enable secure, limited-time API access.**
    

### **Summary: How They Work Together**

| **Level** | **Purpose** | **What Can Be Set Here?** |
| --- | --- | --- |
| **Service Account** | Defines identity & permissions | **Roles, permissions, and scope** (Account/Org/Project) |
| **API Key** | Authentication credential | **Scoped to a Service Account** (inherits permissions) |
| **Token** | Temporary authentication | **Expiration, rotation, and single-use access** |

The table below provides a high-level "before and after" comparison. Please see the Split (BEFORE) and Harness (AFTER) folders below this one for more specific details.

### **API Key Management in Split vs. Harness**

| **Aspect** | **Split (Before)** | **Harness (After)** |
| --- | --- | --- |
| **Permission Management** | API keys have direct permissions. Each key is assigned roles and scopes individually. | Permissions are managed at the **Service Account** level. API keys inherit permissions from their parent Service Account. |
| **Scope Management** | API keys define their own scope (workspace, users, groups, etc.). | Scope is determined by **Resource Groups**, which define what a role can access. |
| **User/Principal Management** | No concept of Service Accounts. API keys function independently. | API keys belong to a **Service Account**, which acts as the principal entity managing access. |
| **Key Expiration & Rotation** | No built-in expiration mechanism. Rotation requires manually deleting and recreating the key. | Tokens provide built-in expiration and can be rotated without deleting the API key. |
| **Access Control** | API keys must be manually added to permission lists to maintain access to restricted resources. | Access is determined by **Role Assignments (Role Bindings)**, which associate a user, group, or Service Account with a role and resource group. |
| **Security Model** | Less granular; API keys can be overly permissive. | More granular; permissions are set at the **Service Account** level, reducing excessive privileges. |
| **Hierarchy of API Key Management** | Flat structure—each API key operates independently. | Hierarchical structure—Service Accounts own API keys, and API keys generate tokens for secure authentication. |

item.name: Restrictions
Split (BEFORE)
item.description:
The `/restrictions` endpoint becomes unavailable to you once your account has been migrated to Harness.

This endpoint is used in Split for managing view restrictions on a project.

Please see the more detailed overview in the this folder's parent folder.

item.description:
The `/roleassignments`, `/role`, and `/resourcegroup` endpoints here replace the Split `/restrictions` endpoint after your migration to Harness.

The examples in this folder demonstrate the power of Harness' RBAC structure for managing any sort of resource, not just a project. Please see the overview in the "Restrictions" folder (parent to this folder) for more context before you dive in here.

### **Before and After of Restrictions in Split vs. Harness**

#### **Before (Split)**

- **Restrictions were applied at the project (workspace) level** using an API endpoint.
    
- To restrict a project, users had to manually specify:
    
    - The list of users/groups allowed access.
        
    - The **Administrator group** as an allowed subject.
        
    - The **API key used to set restrictions** had to be explicitly added as an allowed subject.
        
- Access control was managed via the **resourcePermissions.view** field.
    
- Open projects had no access restrictions, while restricted ones required explicit access grants​
    

#### **After (Harness - RBAC Model)**

- **Permissions are captured in a role** (e.g., `project_viewer`, `fme_manager`).
    
- **Scope is captured in a resource group** (e.g., `_fme_all_resources` for all features within a project).
    
- **Roles and resource groups are assigned to a user (or other principal) via a role binding**.
    
- Projects are **restricted by default** in Harness. If a migrated project was open in Split, Harness assigns broad access to mimic that behavior.
    
- To restrict access post-migration, the **default role bindings for all users/groups must be removed**, and explicit assignments should be made​
    

### **Before and After of Restrictions in Split vs. Harness**

#### **Before (Split)**

- **Restrictions were applied at the project (workspace) level** using an API endpoint.
    
- To restrict a project, users had to manually specify:
    
    - The list of users/groups allowed access.
        
    - The **Administrator group** as an allowed subject.
        
    - The **API key used to set restrictions** had to be explicitly added as an allowed subject.
        
- Access control was managed via the **resourcePermissions.view** field.
    
- Open projects had no access restrictions, while restricted ones required explicit access grants.
    

#### **After (Harness - RBAC Model)**

- **Permissions are captured in a role** (e.g., `project_viewer`, `fme_manager`).
    
- **Scope is captured in a resource group** (e.g., `_fme_all_resources` for all features within a project).
    
- **Roles and resource groups are assigned to a user (or other principal) via a role binding**.
    
- Projects are **restricted by default** in Harness. If a migrated project was open in Split, Harness assigns broad access to mimic that behavior.
    
- To restrict access post-migration, the **default role bindings for all users/groups in that project must be removed**, and explicit assignments should be made.
    

---

These resources in the Harness Developer Hub provide more information on managing roles, resource groups, and role assignments within Harness.

- **Roles**: [Manage roles](https://developer.harness.io/docs/platform/role-based-access-control/add-manage-roles/)
    
- **Resource Groups**: [Manage resource groups](https://developer.harness.io/docs/platform/role-based-access-control/add-resource-groups/)
    
- **Role Assignments (Role Binding)**: [Role-based access control (RBAC) in Harness](https://developer.harness.io/docs/platform/role-based-access-control/rbac-in-harness/)
